children.text: Standard 1: Reading: CONVENTIONS AND SKILLS: Use knowledge of the conventions of language and texts to construct meaning for a range of literary and informational texts for a variety of purposes
Concepts of Print
Recognize that spoken words correspond to printed words, how letters and words are oriented on the page, and that words are read from left-to-right across the page
Recognize the differences between letters, words, and sentences
Recognize that specific sequences of letters represent spoken words
Recognize that capitalization and punctuation are used to distinguish sentences in print materials
Phonemic Awareness
Compare sounds in similar and unlike words
Produce basic rhymes in orally presented words
Orally segment and blend simple syllables
Segment and blend onset-rimes
Segment and blend individual phonemes
Orally substitute and manipulate phonemes
Alphabetic Understanding
Recognize all letters by sight and recall the basic sound attributed to each letter
Identify basic high-frequency words
Decode one-syllable words
Decode words with consonant blends and words with letter combinations
Use common word parts to decode new words
Use meaning-based word recognition strategies to read words
Produce common letter combinations
Use advanced phonic elements (e.g., diphthongs, digraphs), special vowel spelling, and word endings when reading
Use structural clues to read compound words, contractions, possessives, and inflectional endings
Apply syllabication and knowledge of word structure to recognize two- and three-syllable words
Use knowledge of sounds and letters to decode regular multi-syllabic words
Use common word parts and structures to read new words
Vocabulary and Concept Development
Uses words to describe location, size, color, shape, and concepts (e.g., same, different, fast, slow) in speaking situations.
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary learned through stories and instruction
Recognize grade-appropriate categories of words
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary introduced in stories and informational texts
Use previous experiences to understand words in texts
Identify grade-appropriate high-frequency words
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary introduced in stories and informational texts
Identify relationships among common synonyms and antonyms
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including homophones and homographs, introduced in stories, informational texts, word study, and reading

Use hierarchies (e.g., specific to concrete, formal and informal) and categories (e.g., parts of speech, comparative and superlative forms, words with multiple meanings) to read increasingly complex words
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including homophones and homographs, learned through reading and word study, including root words, affixes, and word origins
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary learned through reading print and online resources and word study, including meanings of roots, affixes, word origins
Use grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study, including structural analysis of word parts
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through word study and reading
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study
Use new grade-appropriate vocabulary, including content area vocabulary, learned through reading and word study
Fluency
Read aloud with reasonable accuracy and at an appropriate rate while adhering to end punctuation
Read aloud a grade-appropriate text with fluency and expression
Read grade-appropriate narrative and informational text aloud with fluency and accuracy
Locating Sources/Gathering Information
Recognize the specific information offered by different parts of a book
Locate information in a variety of grade-appropriate resources
Locate information in a variety of grade-appropriate sources
Use print and online resources to clarify meaning and usage
Use a variety of grade-appropriate print and online resources to research a topic
Use grade-appropriate online and print sources to research a topic
Use a variety of grade-appropriate print and online sources to research an inquiry question
Select appropriate information after evaluating the usefulness of print and online resources to investigate a theme, answer a question, or test a hypothesis
Use a variety of strategies to gain information from print and online resources, both primary and secondary, as part of a research plan to support a thesis
Independently use a variety of strategies to gain information from print and online resources, both primary and secondary, as part of a research plan to support a thesis
Use primary and secondary sources to develop and modify a research plan in response to problems and opportunities encountered in accessing print and online resources to support a thesis

Use primary and secondary sources to develop and modify a research plan in response to problems and opportunities encountered in accessing print and online resources to resolve conflicting information
Standard 2: Reading: READING COMPREHENSION: Use reading strategies to construct meaning from a variety of texts
Understanding Text Structures
Use pictures and titles to make predictions about a text
Explain how a title page, illustrations, and key words can convey information
Use title, table of contents, and chapter headings to locate information in informational texts
Describe how the organizational structures of informational and literary texts reflect their different purposes
Describe how common graphic structures (e.g., typeface, headings, illustrations) organize information in texts
Use organizational patterns (e.g., sequential, cause and effect) to access and understand information
Describe and use text structures common to many texts (e.g., index, glossary, bibliography)
Use organizational patterns (e.g., compare and contrast, proposition and support) to access information
Compare structures of texts and apply those that are most appropriate for a given purpose
Use the organizational patterns and text structures of grade-appropriate texts to construct meaning
Use the organizational patterns and text structures of grade-appropriate texts to construct meaning
Constructing Meaning
Retell information from familiar oral or printed text
Make and confirm predictions about what will happen next or what will be learned from a text by previewing key words and illustrations
Use previous experiences to understand topics and concepts in texts
Restate important information or ideas from a variety of texts
Ask and answer who, what, when, why, where, and how questions about what is read
Make, confirm, and modify predictions about a text
Use previous experience and prior knowledge to make connections with subjects and ideas encountered in texts
Confirm or revise predictions after locating evidence in the text
Identify the main idea or problem and solution in a text
Distinguish fact from opinion and cause from effect when reading informational texts
Summarize main points found in informational texts
Make inferences and draw conclusions about grade-appropriate texts
Distinguish between explicit and implied information
Use knowledge of organizational structures (e.g., logical, classification) to construct meaning from texts
Draw and support conclusions about information or ideas in a text
Identify evidence used to support an argument
Use annotation to identify questions and connections to prior knowledge while reading a variety of texts
Evaluate the adequacy and accuracy of an author's evidence in support of his or her main points or argument
Use paraphrasing and summarizing to explain a text
Use annotation methods to identify main ideas and important details while reading
Draw conclusions about the reliability of information in a text after considering author's credentials
Make inferences based on explicit and implied information
Use annotation methods to identify organizational patterns and to make inferences while reading
Analyze questions not answered by a selected text
Use annotation to evaluate the use of evidence while reading a variety of texts
Use a variety of criteria (e.g., clarity, accuracy, author's bias, use of persuasion) to evaluate information
Uses a variety of criteria (e.g., effectiveness of organization, logic, propaganda techniques, authenticity, appeal to audience) to evaluate information
Standard 3: Reading: LITERARY RESPONSE AND ANALYSIS: Respond to literary texts from a range of stances: personal, interpretive, critical
Interpretive Stance
Retell familiar stories, using beginning, middle, and ending
Identify author's message or underlying theme in fiction
Explain main ideas or events that develop the author's message or underlying theme
Compare characters, settings, and plots of two or more stories
Explain the problem or conflict in a story and how it is resolved
Explain how a theme is used across various genres and texts
Cite specific information or ideas in the text that support and develop the author's message or theme
Explain the relationship between plot events and how they build to the resolution of the selection's primary conflict
Explain how characters evolve over the course of a work
Analyze plot, setting, characterization, or conflict to interpret theme in a literary text
Analyze plot, character, theme, dialogue, description, point of view, and other conventions of fiction
Describe how a common theme is developed in two or more texts
Explain similarities and differences between themes from two or more texts
Use textual evidence (e.g., knowledge of rhetorical and literary devices) to interpret and draw conclusions about literature
Use multiple interpretations of text to support or modify own opinion
Explain how the theme or meaning of a literary text can represent a view or comment on life
Literary Elements
Identify characters and setting in a story read aloud
Identify the basic story elements of character and setting
Identify the story elements of character, plot, and setting
Identify basic characteristics of familiar genres (e.g., stories, poems, textbook)
Explain the difference between figurative and literal language
Describe the comparisons made by similes and metaphors
Identify the meaning of common idioms (e.g., from the frying pan into the fire, cat got your tongue, raining cats and dogs) found in a text
Identify and give examples of stylistic elements (e.g., rhyme scheme, rhythm, alliteration)
Explain how personification and hyperbole enhance the meaning of the text
Describe literary devices (e.g., sarcasm, symbolism) and stylistic elements (e.g., simile, metaphor, personification)
Explain literary devices (e.g., satire, allusion, irony)
Analyze the way literary elements and forms are used in prose and poetry
Explain how genre conventions and literary devices support an author's message and purpose
Personal Connection
Relate personal experiences to what was read
State a personal opinion about a fictional selection
State and support a personal opinion about a text
Analyze similarities and differences between the actions, motives, and appearance of a character in a narrative text and self or people in own life
Describe similarities and differences between characters and themes in literary texts and personal or real world experiences
Explain how the author's description of setting and characters and his/her development of plot connect to self
Explain how the author's style and use of language affect the reader
Use prior experience and knowledge to interpret and analyze texts
Explain an opinion about an author's ideas or message by analyzing conventions of fiction ( e.g., plot, character, imagery, motifs, tone, subplots, stock characters)
Explain how previous experience can influence one's reading of a text and one's opinion of that text
Explain how literature can deepen and broaden personal experiences and give insight into problems or issues
Critical Stance
Explain how the author's choice of language and use of literary elements contribute to the author's purpose and the effectiveness of the text
Compare a literary element (e.g., characters, setting, plot) as it occurs in two or more texts and explain how effectively it is realized in each text
Describe how the author's choice of words or use of imagery contributes to overall quality and reader's enjoyment
Explain how an author's background is reflected in literature, including the use of language
Describe how historical or cultural influences help explain a text
Analyze a text to draw inferences about history, culture, or gender
Recognize the similarities and differences between the styles of two or more writers
Explain how historical and cultural information enriches the interpretation of a text
Describe independently how a literary text is related to historical and cultural themes and issues
Describe similarities and differences in content, literary form, and/or style in two or more selections of literature
Analyze how a literary text is related to historical, cultural, and/or political themes and issues (e.g., women's place in society, sovereignty of native groups)
Evaluate how an author's purpose and message are supported by his/her construction of text and use of literary devices
Identify the social or political assumptions in a literary text

Standard 4: Writing: CONVENTIONS AND SKILLS: Use the writing process and conventions of language and research to construct meaning and communicate effectively for a variety of purposes and audiences using a range of forms
Range of Writing
Write for a variety of purposes related to daily class activities and own life
Describe familiar topics and convey thoughts, ideas, and basic information using pictures and phonetically spelled words

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • descriptions about familiar people, places, events, or experiences
  • non-fiction formats that explain or give basic informatin about familiar topics
  • reflections on learning

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • brief narratives with logical sequencing and some detail
  • simple explanations of an event or circumstance

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • stories with a beginning, middle, and end and poems with sensory details
  • short reports on content area topics
  • pieces related to completing tasks
  • friendly letters
  • responses to literature
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives that follow a plot and describe a setting and characters
  • poems that provide insight into why the topic is memorable
  • responses to literature
  • reports that focus on a central question and incorporate summaries from research
  • accounts based on personal experience that have a clear focus and supporting details
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives that include plot, setting, characters, and a conflict
  • poems that use figurative language to convey a theme or impression
  • reports incorporating a framing question and including research from two or more sources
  • responses to literature
  • pieces related to completing tasks
  • notes summarizing what they have read or heard
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives that establish a point of view and experiment with a range of devices (i.e., dialogue, suspense, flashback)
  • poems that experiment with poetic devices (figurative language, graphic elements) to convey a theme or impression
  • reports with a narrowed focus that allows for thorough treatment
  • business letters
  • responses to literature
  • functional pieces that complete a task or fulfill a civic responsibility
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives with clear conflict and satisfying resolution
  • poems that experiment with poetic forms (i.e., limerick, ballad, free verse)
  • reports that incorporate research in the form of quotations, paraphrases, and summaries
  • persuasive letters or statements
  • responses to literature
  • functional pieces that complete a task or fulfill a civic responsibility
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives that reveal the significance of the subject or situation
  • poems that use a range of poetic devices and forms
  • reports that incorporate research and distinguish the relative value of research sources
  • persuasive statements that anticipate and address reader's questions
  • responses to literature
  • functional pieces that complete a task or fulfill a civic responsibility
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives or scripts with a theme and details that contribute to a mood or tone
  • poems using a range of poetic techniques and figurative language in a variety of forms
  • literary, persuasive, and personal essays
  • research papers that state and support a thesis
  • functional writing including forms, applications, and questionnaires
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives or scripts with a theme and details that contribute to a mood or tone
  • poems using a range of poetic techniques and figurative language in a variety of forms
  • literary, persuasive, and personal essays
  • research papers that state and support a thesis
  • functional writing including forms, applications, and questionnaires
  • pieces to reflect on learning and to solve problems

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives or scripts with a theme and details that contribute to a mood or tone
  • poems using a range of poetic techniques and figurative language in a variety of forms
  • literary, persuasive, and personal essays that demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the topic
  • research papers that include two or more relevant perspectives and take into consideration the validity and reliability of sources
  • functional writing including college and job applications
  • reflections that draw comparisons between specific incidents and broader themes

Write in a variety of grade-appropriate formats for a variety of purposes and audiences, such as:
  • narratives or scripts with a theme and details that contribute to a mood or tone
  • poems using a range of poetic techniques and figurative language in a variety of forms
  • literary, persuasive, and personal essays that demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the topic
  • research papers that include two or more relevant perspectives and take into consideration the validity and reliability of sources
  • functional writing including college and job applications
  • reflections that draw comparisons between specific incidents and broader themes
Spelling and Handwriting
Write upper-and lower-case letters independently, attending to form and spatial alignment
Use phonetic spelling to write new words
Use correct spelling for own name, commonly used high-frequency words, and words in environmental print
Punctuation, Capitalization, Spelling, and Handwriting
Print legibly using correct spacing, capital letters, and end punctuation to distinguish words and sentences
Use letter-sound knowledge and segmenting strategies to spell unfamiliar words

Edit writing to correct capitalization:
  • The pronoun / and proper names

Edit writing to correct use of the following punctuation:
  • periods as end marks
Spell grade-appropriate high-frequency words and words with basic short-vowel, long-vowel, and consonant-blend patterns

Edit writing to correct capitalization:
  • proper nouns
  • words at the beginning of sentences
  • days of the week
  • months of the year

Edit writing to correct use of following punctuation:
  • apostrophes in common contractions, including don't, isn't , and can't
  • question marks and exclamation points
Print legibly and space letters, words, and sentences appropriately
Spell grade-appropriate high-frequency words; irregular plurals; common homophones; and words that have blends, contractions, and orthographic patterns

Edit writing to correct use of following punctuation:
  • commas in letters, dates, addresses, and items in a simple series
  • apostrophes in contractions and singular possessives
  • quotation marks and commas or end marks in direct quotations and dialogue

Edit writing to correct capitalization:
  • geographical names
  • special events
  • titles and initials of people
Write legibly, adhering to margins and correct spacing between letters in a word and words in a sentence
Spell grade-appropriate words that have a variety of spelling patterns

Edit writing to correct use of following punctuation:
  • commas in a series of multi-word items, in compound sentences, and after introductory phrases
  • apostrophes in contractions with pronouns
  • underlining/italics or quotation marks, as appropriate, to indicate titles

LA.4.4.5 Edit writing to correct capitalization:
  • first and important words in a title
  • historical periods
  • special events
Write legibly and fluently in print or cursive
Punctuation, Capitalization, and Spelling
Use a variety of strategies and resources to spell grade-appropriate words

Edit writing to correct use of following punctuation:
  • parentheses
  • commas with relative clauses
  • commas with appositives, if needed

Edit writing to correct punctuation:
  • commas in direct address
  • colon after salutation
  • hyphens in written numbers
  • italics or underlining for emphasis
  • semicolons to join related independent clauses
Use a variety of strategies and resources to spell grade-appropriate words

Edit writing to correct punctuation:
  • commas to set off non-restrictive relative clauses
  • comma to set off interrupters
Use a variety of strategies and resources to spell grade-appropriate words

Edit writing to correct punctuation:
  • dash to interrupt thought
  • brackets to enclose information
  • semicolon to separate items in a series that contain internal commas
Use a variety of strategies and resources to spell grade-appropriate words

Edit writing to correct punctuation:
  • ellipsis
  • italics/underlining for foreign words
Use a variety of strategies and resources to spell grade-appropriate words
Sentence Structure and Grammar
Write complete sentences

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • correct word order when constructing complete sentences
  • declarative, interrogative, and exclamatory sentences
  • plural forms of regular nouns
  • adjectives

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • imperative sentences
  • past, present, and future verb tenses
  • subject-verb agreement with single-word subject
  • plural forms of irregular nouns
  • adverbs

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • compound sentences
  • dialogue
  • forms of common irregular nouns and verbs
  • subject-verb agreement with compound subjects
  • plural possessives
  • transitional words

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • complex sentences
  • introductory phrases and subordinate clauses
  • noun-pronoun agreement with intervening words or phrases
  • appositives
  • relative clauses
Recognize and correct run-on sentences and fragments

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • consistent verb tense across paragraphs
  • comparative and superlative forms of adjectives
  • coordinating and subordinating conjunctions
  • prepositional phrases
  • compound sentence joined by semicolon rather than conjunction and comma
  • subject-verb agreement with intervening phrase

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • numbers represented using numerals or words, whichever is appropriate
  • comparative and superlative forms of adverbs
  • compound-complex sentences

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • present perfect, past perfect, and future perfect tenses
  • subject-verb agreement with compound subjects

Form and use the following grammatical constructions correctly when editing writing:
  • parallel structures in various contexts (e.g., items in a series, complements, items juxtaposed for emphasis)
  • subordination and coordination to indicate relationship between ideas
  • restrictive clauses with appropriate use of that
  • abbreviations used in research citation
Grammar and Mechanics
Use knowledge of sentence structure, grammar, punctuation, capitalization, and spelling to produce grade-appropriate writing in standard English
Use knowledge of sentence structure, grammar, punctuation, capitalization, and spelling to produce grade-appropriate writing in standard English
Use knowledge of sentence structure, grammar, punctuation, capitalization, and spelling to produce grade-appropriate writing in standard English
Citing Sources
Differentiate between own information and information from other sources
Write a simple bibliography entry for a book and website (e.g., author, title, publisher, copyright)
Write bibliographical entries for periodicals
Incorporate information from references by quoting, paraphrasing, and/or summarizing
Describe the reasons for citing sources (e.g., giving credit to original source, providing information for readers to follow up on an idea)
Cite various grade-appropriate sources using a consistent format when reporting information
Cite various grade-appropriate sources using a consistent format when reporting information
Cite various grade-appropriate sources using a consistent format when reporting information
Describe the meaning and consequences of plagiarism
Use a prescribed documentation style to adhere to fair use and copyright guidelines for citing grade-appropriate sources in papers, projects, and multimedia presentations
Use quotations and citations in writing while maintaining the flow of ideas
Use a prescribed documentation style to adhere to fair use and copyright guidelines for citing grade-appropriate sources in papers, projects, and multimedia presentations
Use quotations and citations in writing to achieve effective balance between researched information and original ideas
Synthesize and cite information from multiple sources (e.g., almanacs, websites, periodicals, field studies, speeches, interviews) while maintaining the flow of ideas
Use grade-appropriate conventions for documentation in text, notes, and bibliographies

Synthesize and cite information from multiple sources (e.g., works of art, works cited within other works, a work appearing in an anthology, an unpublished manuscript) while maintaining the flow of ideas
Use grade-appropriate conventions for documentation in text, notes, and bibliographies
Standard 5: Writing: RHETORIC: Use rhetorical devices to craft writing appropriate to audience and purpose
Meaning
Add detail to drawings and other products with simple descriptive words
Focus on a single topic in a piece of writing
Add simple descriptions and details to develop a topic
Choose and maintain a focus in a single piece of writing
Add details, descriptions, and information from different sources to elaborate meaning
Use appropriate facts and interesting details that develop the intended meaning and anticipate the needs of the audience
Use information from appropriate sources: self, peers, and a variety of grade-appropriate sources
Use significant details and relevant information to develop meaning
Select appropriate details, examples, reasons, and/or facts to support an insight, message, or thesis
Connect selected details, examples, reasons, and/or facts to the insight, message, or thesis in a meaningful way
Use relevant ideas and details in writing to show insight into people, events, new knowledge, and personal background
Use accurate and useful research information in writing
Establish a controlling focus that guides the reader to the intended insight, message, or thesis of the piece
Develop ideas and details in writing to address a specific purpose and audience
Develop ideas and details in writing to enlarge the effect or scope of the piece while addressing a specific purpose and audience
Design
Use spacing and appropriate sizes of letters, words, titles, and pictures to show a rudimentary sense of form
Add titles and sequence ideas to organize writing
Add details from personal experience to elaborate upon and amplify ideas
Use a beginning, middle, and ending in a piece of writing
Organize information by introducing it, elaborating on it, and drawing a conclusion about it
Group related ideas into paragraphs
Use paragraphs and transitions to organize related information and move the reader from one idea to the next
Organize writing to exclude extraneous details and inconsistencies
Use transitional words or phrases between sentences and paragraphs to guide the reader and give the writing cohesiveness
Use an organizational structure (e.g., chronological, comparison and contrast, spatial order, climactic order, order of importance) to support meaning
Use an organizational structure that unites the parts of the piece of writing and gives it coherence and completeness
Use an organizational structure that maintains proportion among the parts of a piece of writing and gives it coherence.
Use a variety of structural patterns and transitional devices to organize writing
Use an organizational structure that creates fluency between ideas, links ideas to the message, and creates the desired impression
Organize writing so that it conveys a clear perspective on the topic, maintains a consistent focus, and addresses the needs of the audience
Clarity
Use descriptive words when writing about people, places, things, or events
Use specific nouns and adjectives to describe people, places, things, or events
Add or replace phrases and parts of sentences to make meaning clearer or more logical
Use specific verbs and adverbs to describe people, places, things, or events
Write with increased sentence variety by using compound subjects, questions, or dialogue
Use figurative language to emphasize meaning
Use a variety of simple and compound sentence structures for fluency and to support meaning
Use clear and precise vocabulary to support meaning
Improve clarity by combining sentences, varying sentences, or rearranging text
Select words and phrases to establish the desired tone
Vary sentence structure and grammatical forms (e.g., forms of adjectives, prepositional phrases, compound sentences) to improve clarity
Select words and phrases to establish consistency in word usage (e.g., formal, colloquial, technical) throughout the piece of writing
Vary sentence structures and grammatical forms (e.g., forms of adverbs, prepositional phrases, compound, and compound-complex sentences) to improve clarity
Use action verbs, less obvious modifiers, and active rather than passive voice
Vary sentence types (e.g., simple, compound, compound-complex) and word order within a sentence to improve clarity
Use a variety of sentence structures (e.g., parallel phrasing, subordination) and grade-appropriate vocabulary to achieve efficiency, indicate emphasis, and clarify meaning
Use a variety of sentence structures and grade-appropriate vocabulary to achieve efficiency, indicate emphasis, clarify meaning
Use a variety of sentence structures and grade-appropriate vocabulary to achieve the intended message
Use a variety of sentence structures and grade-appropriate vocabulary to achieve intended message
Voice
Convey enthusiasm for the topic
Adjust voice to suit the purpose and form of writing (e.g., funny story, report, serious poem)
Adjust voice to suit the audience and situation (e.g., informal note to a peer, business letter to organization, research report)
Use words, phrases, and sentence construction to begin to establish an individual rather than a generic voice
Use words, phrases, and sentence construction to create a consistent voice throughout a piece of writing
Use a voice and tone appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience

Standard 6: Oral Communication: CONVENTIONS AND SKILLS: Apply knowledge of verbal and nonverbal language to communicate effectively in various situations: interpersonal, group, and public: for a variety of purposes
Discussion and Presentation
Express ideas through simple activities (e.g., creative movement, choral speaking, show and tell, rhymes, poems and songs)
Use basic social conventions in greetings, in introductions, and in conversations
Ask and respond appropriately to basic questions
Express ideas through drama activities (e.g., sharing, role playing, puppetry, mime, choral reading)
Use appropriate social conventions (e.g., waiting one's turn, raising a hand, apologizing) in various large and small group situations
Give and follow one- to three-step oral directions
Use oral language to obtain information, complete a task, and share ideas with others
Give an oral presentation to share information with peers
Express ideas through drama activities (e.g., role playing, skits, puppetry, choral reading, story telling)
Use appropriate social conventions in various large and small group situations
Use oral language to obtain information, complete a task, and share ideas and personal opinions with others
Give a planned speech to share information with peers
Participate in grade-appropriate oral group activities
Give short, informal presentations to inform or persuade
Use speaking and listening skills to fill a prescribed role in group activities
Give informal presentations or reports to inform
Explain how appropriate participation affects the productivity of group activities
Use language that facilitates open communication (e.g., phrasing comments in a positive way, using descriptive language to communicate a point)
Give short prepared oral presentations to inform and persuade
Adjust one's role in a small group, as necessary, in order to carry out an assignment or to complete a project
Give short prepared oral presentations incorporating information from research to inform and persuade
Monitor the roles in a small group and adjust communication as needed to make the group effort more productive
Give oral presentations to inform, persuade, and/or entertain
Conduct interviews using effective questioning, listening, and note-taking skills
Organize and participate in a small group to accomplish a task or explore a topic
Give a planned oral presentation highlighting a main idea(s) with support (e.g., statistics, anecdotes, examples)
Participate in a small group (e.g., plan sessions, decide on procedures, plan sessions, assign responsibilities, evaluate results)
Give a planned oral presentation, adopting a position or explaining a point of view
Use criteria that describe roles to ensure the participation of all members of a group
Participate in a small group (e.g., organize sessions and information, complete a grade-appropriate task, evaluate the group's accomplishments)
Give a planned oral presentation on a topic that is open to more than one point of view
Participate in a small group (e.g., organize sessions and information, complete a grade-appropriate task, evaluate the group's accomplishments)
Give a planned oral presentation to support a position on a specified topic and respond to questions from the audience
Critical Listening
Follow simple oral directions, instructions, and explanations
Ask questions for clarification
Use basic listening skills to focus attention on speaker and respond to a message
Give feedback to a speaker to promote mutual understanding
Give verbal and nonverbal feedback to a speaker to promote mutual understanding
Clarify spoken messages by restating, questioning, or elaborating
Use visual structures and summarize key ideas when listening to oral messages in order to improve comprehension
Distinguish between supporting facts and opinions in oral messages
Recall oral messages by noting key ideas and relating them to the speaker's purpose
Form an opinion or draw a conclusion about key points in oral messages
Use appropriate listening strategies (e.g., listening attentively, taking notes, asking questions) to learn from an oral presentation
Find out needed information by asking thoughtful questions
Check comprehension before responding to a message by using various listening strategies (e.g., noting nonverbal cues, clarifying message by summarizing aloud)
Use appropriate attentive, responsive, and reflective listening behaviors according to situation
Use supportive responses to encourage a speaker
Listen to establish the strength of the evidence in support of the main point(s)
Listen to assess the reasonableness of the position or argum
Listen to determine the evidence for and against a given position or argument
Delivery
Use appropriate volume when speaking in various situations
Use eye contact as a listening and speaking skill to focus attention on the speaker or connect with listener(s)
Adjust volume and intonation (e.g., falling for statements, rising for questions) as appropriate to content and purpose
Adjust pacing, volume, and intonation appropriate to content and purpose

Media Comprehension and Interpretation
Identify techniques used to convey messages in visual media
Describe how advertising techniques are used in various media
Describe a variety of messages conveyed by visual media
Evaluate informational media using a variety of criteria (e.g., publication date, relevance, accessibility)

Standard 7: Oral Communication: RHETORIC: Adapt messages appropriately to address audience, purpose, and situation
Meaning
Use personal experiences as a topic when speaking
Use personal examples and explanations to make ideas clearer in various speaking situations
Add details and information to support ideas when speaking
Add concrete details and specific facts to support and develop ideas when speaking
Use prior knowledge, input from others, and text resources to develop ideas for speaking
Add details to support meaning
Combine ideas from prior knowledge, input from others, and text resources to elaborate on and support ideas
Use relevant evidence and examples to support content
Integrate facts, information, and ideas from research with own experience to support main ideas when speaking
Select most appropriate information from research, own experience, and knowledge of audience to support ideas when speaking
Use credible sources to support ideas in oral messages
Incorporate information from a range of print and online sources
Use information about audience to incorporate ideas or approaches that will increase interest and acceptance
Use relevant evidence and rhetorical devices to advocate and defend a position
Design
Present events in chronological order
Present ideas in a logical order or sequence that is easy to follow
Organize ideas in a simple organization pattern or logical sequence so listeners can understand them
Group similar ideas around major points when speaking
Organize a speech to emphasize important points and relate them to one another
Include an introduction, transitions, and a conclusion to organize speaking
Organize information to create a succinct message
Use an organizational pattern that creates a clear message and guides the listener
Follow a logical pattern of organization to plan a speech that informs or persuades
Use speaking and listening strategies to plan and organize content for a specific audience
Use an introduction that captures interest and a conclusion that brings the topic to a satisfactory closing
Use transitions effectively to organize content and ideas when speaking
Organize points so as to lead the audience to seriously consider an argument or stance
Clarity
Use appropriate words when speaking
Use clear and appropriate vocabulary when speaking
Use complete sentences when speaking
Use clear and specific vocabulary to convey the intended message
Select words and phrases that clarify the message when speaking
Select words and construct sentences to clarify message when speaking
Use appropriate verbal and nonverbal language for various purposes and audiences
Use precise vocabulary suited to topic and audience
Use words that convey a viewpoint and fit audience and purpose
Construct sentences and select words in order to emphasize important points
Selects specific words to elicit a desired response when speaking
Use rhetorical devices (e.g., rhetorical question, parallel structure, repetition) to highlight key ideas when speaking
Use language that shows authority, conviction, and knowledge of topic
